awd_titl_txt: Experimental Study of Mineral Solubility in Fluids of the Deep Crust and Upper Mantle
awd_abstract_narration:
Fluids in Earth's deep crust and upper mantle play an important role in a wide range of geological processes. They change rock compositions, participate in crustal and mantle melting, and mediate how rocks deform. Their ability to change rock composition figures prominently in Earth?s long term compositional evolution that resulted in formation of the continental crust on which we live. The action of fluids in deep environments is a fundamental aspect of melting that leads to large volcanoes whose volatile content governs explosivity and therefore the hazards they pose. By controlling how rocks deform, fluids in deep settings also play a poorly understood role in deep, slow-slip earthquakes whose generation we are only now beginning to understand.

This project aims to experimentally characterize the basic physical chemistry of how water interacts with and dissolves minerals in the deep crust and upper mantle. It is proposed to conduct experiments in three areas. The first will provide robust thermodynamic constraints on the speciation of aqueous silica, the most abundant neutral species at most crustal conditions. A second component of the work focuses on dissolved Si at alkaline conditions. This is because models suggest that the pH crustal and mantle fluids is alkaline over a wide range of P and T. Finally. the team will extend previous experiments on quartz and feldspar solubility in H2O-salt solutions to include CaCl2 and anorthite, which have not previously been studied but which are key ingredients to any understanding of deep fluids. All experiments will involve hydrothermal piston-cylinder methods which provide precise and accurate solubility constraints at the requisite conditions. The work will provide constraints that will help improve new models of the chemistry of fluid-rock interaction at high pressure and temperature.

por.por_cntn:
Fluids are important for the evolution and properties of Earth’s crust and mantle. Fluids in these deep environments promote deformation, such as folding and earthquakes, while powering the transfers and enrichments of chemical elements in hydrothermal systems and ore deposits. This project focused on the chemistry of fluids at temperatures and depths corresponding to the middle and lower crust and upper mantle (15-50 km depth). In these deeper environments, fluids are made up of four main components: H2O, nonpolar gases, salts, and rock-derived solutes. The different components lead to a wide range of composition, varying capacity to dissolve rock constituents, and potential for separation of into multiple fluid phases with different chemical properties.

Central to understanding these fluids and their interactions with the rocks that host them is determining the solubility and forms of dissolved silica. This is because silica is the most abundant oxide component in the rocks, and it is typically the most soluble oxide component from the rock. This project examined silica solubility in deep fluids using experimental approaches aimed at measuring silica concentrations and constraining its forms in solution. We showed how salts and carbon dioxide influence the solubility of the simplest silica mineral, quartz, at a range of pressures and temperatures. We also determined the influence of fluid acidity on quartz solubility. Finally, we evaluated how other rock components, such as aluminum, affect the amount and form of dissolved silica.

The work led to 14 publications by the time of completion, with further contributions still in progress. The project also motivated additional investigations in our laboratory into the influence of carbon dioxide in other deep earth contexts, such as silicate and carbonate magmas. Because fluids are integral to the complex processes linking subduction to arc magmatism, our work also generated new insights into element budgets and chemical processing in this environment. The studies are laying a foundation for new models of deep fluids of the lower crust and upper mantle.
